data.title: Rapper NS at the studio
data.solution:
track = input()

# Step 1: move any 3+ consecutive same notes to the end
i = 0
fixed_track = []
glitches = []
while i < len(track):
    count = 1
    while i + count < len(track) and track[i + count] == track[i]:
        count += 1
    if count >= 3:
        glitches.extend(track[i:i+count])
    else:
        fixed_track.extend(track[i:i+count])
    i += count

track = ''.join(fixed_track + glitches)

# Step 2: sort by note strength
order = {'n': 0, 'l': 1, 'm': 2, 'h': 3, 'x': 4}
sorted_track = sorted(track, key=lambda x: order[x], reverse=len(track)%2==1)
print(''.join(sorted_track))
data.statement:
Rapper NS is recording a new hit, but his autotune plugin has gone haywire. Each note has one of 5 possible effects:

n = No effect
l = Light
m = Medium
h = Heavy
x = Extreme

He wants the track balanced:
- If the number of notes is even, sort the notes in ascending strength: n < l < m < h < x.
- If the number of notes is odd, sort the notes in descending strength: x > h > m > l > n.

Help NS fix his track!
data.constraints:
- The track length can be up to 100 characters
- Only letters n, l, m, h, x are used in [[track]]

lastVersion.statementHTML:
Goal

Rapper NS is recording a new hit, but his autotune plugin has gone haywire. Each note has one of 5 possible effects:

n = No effect
l = Light
m = Medium
h = Heavy
x = Extreme

He wants the track balanced:
- If the number of notes is even, sort the notes in ascending strength: n < l < m < h < x.
- If the number of notes is odd, sort the notes in descending strength: x > h > m > l > n.

Help NS fix his track!
Input
Line 1 (a string) track of notes with autotune effects
Output
A single line str with the fixed track
Constraints
- The track length can be up to 100 characters
- Only letters n, l, m, h, x are used in track
Example
Input
xlxxhxmlmxhmhlxm
Output
lllmmmmhhhxxxxxx
